analyze_foundations.description: Analyze content for triggered moral foundations using Jonathan Haidt's framework

framework.title: MORAL FOUNDATIONS THEORY - COMPREHENSIVE FRAMEWORK
framework.intro: Moral Foundations Theory (Jonathan Haidt) identifies six innate psychological systems that shape moral judgment across cultures. These "foundations" are like taste receptorsâ€”everyone has them, but political tribes differ dramatically in which foundations they weight most heavily. Understanding which foundations a piece of content activates reveals its tribal targeting and persuasive strategy.

care.name: CARE/HARM
care.core_concern: Suffering, compassion, nurturing, protection of vulnerable
care.triggered_by: Children in distress, victims of cruelty, medical suffering, vulnerable populations, protective instincts
care.examples: Healthcare access, child welfare, refugee protection, pandemic response, animal welfare

fairness.name: FAIRNESS/CHEATING
fairness.core_concern: Justice, reciprocity, proportionality, equality, rights violations
fairness.triggered_by: Unfair treatment, exploitation, unequal distribution, cheating, rule violations

political_patterns.conservatives: MODERATE (proportional fairness, "you get what you deserve")

fairness.examples: Taxation debates, affirmative action, economic inequality, legal rights, meritocracy vs. equity

loyalty.name: LOYALTY/BETRAYAL
loyalty.core_concern: Group cohesion, patriotism, tribal solidarity, team identity
loyalty.triggered_by: National symbols, in-group pride, betrayal of the group, team sports, military service

political_patterns.progressives: LOW (universal humanity emphasis, skepticism of nationalism)

loyalty.examples: Flag rituals, immigration restrictionism, "anti-American" accusations, "with us or against us" rhetoric

authority.name: AUTHORITY/SUBVERSION
authority.core_concern: Respect for hierarchy, tradition, leadership, social order
authority.triggered_by: Deference to legitimate authority, respect for tradition, order vs. chaos, rebellion against rightful power

political_patterns.conservatives: VERY HIGH (respect for police, military, religious authority, tradition)

authority.examples: "Back the Blue", religious authority, traditional gender roles, "law and order", institutional deference

sanctity.name: SANCTITY/DEGRADATION
sanctity.core_concern: Purity, sacredness, disgust, elevated ideals vs. contamination
sanctity.triggered_by: Purity/contamination, sacred values, moral disgust, spiritual elevation, bodily integrity

political_patterns.progressives: MODERATE-LOW (but can be HIGH around environmental purity, body autonomy as sacred)

sanctity.examples: Sexual morality, religious reverence, "sanctity of life", environmental purity, bodily autonomy, GMO fears

liberty.name: LIBERTY/OPPRESSION
liberty.core_concern: Freedom from domination, resistance to tyranny, individual autonomy
liberty.triggered_by: Tyranny, oppression, bullying, freedom, resistance to control, individual rights
liberty.examples: Free speech, gun rights, vaccine mandates, anti-authoritarianism, liberation movements, "don't tread on me"

key_insights: Progressives rely heavily on Care and Fairness, with lower emphasis on Loyalty, Authority, and Sanctity. This makes progressive messaging focused on suffering reduction and equality.
Conservatives weight all six foundations more evenly, with especially high Loyalty, Authority, and Sanctity. This makes conservative messaging emphasize tradition, order, and group cohesion.
Libertarians spike on Liberty/Oppression and downplay Authority, making them suspicious of both government power and social conformity pressure.

Most political conflict stems from tribes talking past each other because they're activating different moral foundations. What progressives see as compassion (high Care), conservatives may see as naive bleeding-heart sentimentality that ignores group boundaries (low Loyalty) and proper order (low Authority).

Analyze this content using Moral Foundations Theory (Jonathan Haidt).

CONTENT:
{content}

{framework_text}

For each foundation, determine:
1. Is it triggered? (true/false)
2. Intensity (0.0-1.0): How strongly is it invoked?
3. Specific triggers: What language/concepts activate this foundation?
4. Valence: Is it appealed to positively or violated/attacked?

    "care": {{
        "triggered": true/false,
        "intensity": 0.0-1.0,
